article.headline: Arkansas 78, SE Missouri State 68
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Jonathan Modica thought he and his Arkansas teammates were in for a halftime thrashing from coach Stan Heath on Tuesday. The Razorbacks trailed Southeast Missouri State by 10 and hadn't shown much of an offense against a team with troubles winning on the road. But the explosion never happened. Heath calmly told his team it had to stick together and it did, overcoming the deficit to take a 78-68 victory over the Indians. "He really didn't jump down our throats like he should have or like he usually does," said Modica, who led Arkansas in scoring for the sixth straight game this year with 20 points. "He said what he had to say, we responded and we won the game." Heath said he was worried the game might end up like the Razorbacks' loss to Troy State last year. Arkansas followed a tough loss to a ranked Tulsa team with its first loss ever to Troy State last year. Coming off a 23-point loss to No. 14 Illinois on Saturday, Heath was concerned Southeast Missouri, who has lost 11 of 12 on the road, might catch Arkansas in the same funk. At halftime, Heath chose to be positive. "We had a different attitude in the locker room," Heath said. "At halftime we talked about this is why we're down. This is what we're not doing well. This is what we can do to make a difference in this game." The Razorbacks (5-1) crawled back early in the second half and used a 17-4 run to put away Southeast Missouri (4-3). Point guard Eric Ferguson had 18 points for Arkansas, while Ronnie Brewer had 14 and Olu Famutimi finished with 12. Billy Pharis, coming off the bench, had 10 points and led Arkansas with nine rebounds and four assists. "We found a way to win," Heath said. "We would not have won that game last year, I know that. The players know that. We came closer together during this adversity." Southeast Missouri shot well from all over the court in the first half. However, its shooting declined in the second half as they got tired and turned the ball over. Its first five turnovers in the second half led to 10 quick points for Arkansas and the Indians made just 6 of 12 free throws in the second half. "They wore us down out there," Southeast Missouri coach Gary Garner said. "Turnovers made the difference in the game. They had more turnovers in the first half, but we came out and had more in the second half and it cost us a win." Southeast Missouri entered the game 1-9 against teams in the Southeastern Conference, but the sole win was a 28-21 victory over Arkansas in 1925, when the Razorbacks were in the Southwest Conference. Dainmon Gonner led the Indians with 20 points. Brandon Griffin added 16. Arkansas senior guard Charles Tatum hit a 3-pointer to pull Arkansas within 50-48 with about 15 minutes left in the game. It was the closest the Razorbacks had been since the Indians took a 9-7 lead early in the game. Arkansas ripped off a 17-4 run over the next 6{ minutes to take a 65-56 lead. Famutimi, who started his first game, scored seven points during the run, while Pharis had five. Southeast Missouri opened with the hot shooting hand. The Indians made 9 of 12 to open the game and four players made 3-pointers during the first half, when Southeast Missouri made 53.8 percent from the field and 6 of 9 3-pointers. "First half we came out on fire," Gonner said. "We fell asleep in the second half. We didn't rebound or make shots in the second half." The Indians only made one 3-pointer and dropped to 37 percent shooting in the second half.
